facts.text: Punjab High Court judgment in Criminal Appeal No. 326 of 1956.

facts.text: Arising out of judgment dated June 26, 1956, of Sessions Judge at Ferozepore in Sessions Case No. 8 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated June 26, 1956, of the Court of the Sessions Judge at Ferozepore in Sessions Case No. 8 of 1956. Jai Gopal Sethi and R. L. Kohli, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 11, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. March 11. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by 1497 BOSE J.-The appellant Virsa Singh has been sentenced

facts.text: Appellant Virsa Singh sentenced to imprisonment for life under s. 302 IPC for murder of Khem Singh.

anchor.surface_text: BOSE J.-The appellant Virsa Singh has been sentenced to imprisonment for life under s. 302 of the Indian Penal Code for the murder of one Khem Singh.

facts.text: Special leave granted limited to question: on finding accepted by Punjab High Court, what offence made out.

anchor.surface_text: He was granted special leave to appeal by this Court but the leave is limited to the question that on the finding accepted by the Punjab High Court what offence is made out as having been companymitted

facts.text: Appellant tried with five others under ss. 302/49, 324/149, 323/149 IPC, and individually under s.302.

anchor.surface_text: by the petitioner. The appellant was tried with five others under sss. 302/49, 324/149 and 323/149 Indian Penal Code. He was also charged individually under s. 302.

facts.text: Other five acquitted of murder by Sessions Court, convicted under ss. 326, 324, 323/149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The other, were acquitted of the murder charge by the first Court but were companyvicted under ss. 326, 324 and 323 read with s. 149, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: On appeal to High Court, other five acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal to the High Court they were all acquitted. The appellant was companyvicted by the first Court under s. 302

facts.text: Appellant convicted under s.302 by Sessions Court, conviction and sentence upheld by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: and his companyviction and sentence were upheld by the High Court. There was only one injury on Khem Singh and both Courts are agreed

facts.text: Only one injury on Khem Singh, caused by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: There was only one injury on Khem Singh and both Courts are agreed that the appellant caused it.

facts.text: Injury caused by spear thrust.

anchor.surface_text: It was caused as the result of a spear thrust and the doctor who examined Khem Singh, while he was still alive, said that it was a punctured

facts.text: Doctor examined Khem Singh while alive: punctured wound 2 x 1/2" transverse on left side of abdominal wall, lower iliac region above inguinal canal; three coils of intestines out.

anchor.surface_text: wound 2 x 1/2 transverse in direction on the left side of the abdominal wall in the lower part of the iliac region just above the inguinal canal. He also said that Three companyls of intestines were companying out of the wound.

facts.text: Incident occurred about 8 p.m. on July 13, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The incident occurred about 8 p. m. on July 13, 1955. Khem Singh died about 5 p. m. the following day.

facts.text: Khem Singh died about 5 p.m. on July 14, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Khem Singh died about 5 p. m. the following day. The doctor who companyducted the postmortem described the injury as-

facts.text: Postmortem: oblique incised stitched wound 2 1/2" on lower left side of belly, 1 1/2" above left inguinal ligament; through whole thickness of abdominal wall; peritonitis; digested food; flakes of pus on small intestines; six cuts, digested food from three.

anchor.surface_text: an oblique incised stitched wound 21/2 on the lower part of left side of belly, 13 above the left inguinal ligament. The injury was through the whole thickness of the abdominal wall. Peritonitis was present and there was digested food in that cavity. Flakes of pus were sticking round the small intestines 1498 and there were six cuts at various places, and digested food was flowing out from three cuts.

facts.text: Injury sufficient to cause death in ordinary course of nature.

anchor.surface_text: The doctor said that the injury was sufficient to cause death in the ordinary companyrse of nature.

facts.text: Sessions Judge found appellant 21 or 22 years old.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge found that the appellant was 21 or 22 years old and said-

facts.text: Sessions Judge: common object to cause grievous hurt only; no intention to cause death, but rash forceful blow; peritonitis hastened death.

anchor.surface_text: When the companymon object of the assembly seems to have been to cause grievous hurts only, I do number suppose Virsa Singh actually had the intention to cause the death of Khem Singh, but by a rash and silly act he gave a rather forceful blow, which ultimately caused his death. Peritonitis also supervened and that hastened the death of Khem Singh.

facts.text: High Court: whole affair sudden, on chance meeting.

anchor.surface_text: The learned High Court Judges companysidered that the whole affair was sudden and occurred on a chance meeting .

facts.text: Both courts accepted appellant inflicted injury and medical testimony that blow fatal.

anchor.surface_text: But they accepted the finding that the appellant inflicted the injury on Khem Singh and accepted the medical testimony that the blow was a fatal one.

To put it shortly, the prosecution must prove the following facts before it can bring a case under s. 300, 3rdly First, it must establish, quite objectively, that a bodily injury is present Secondly, the nature of the injury must be proved These are purely objective investigations. Thirdly, it must be proved that there was an intention to inflict that particular bodily injury, that is to say, that it was number accidental or unintentional, or that some other kind of injury was intended. 1501 Once these three elements are proved to be present, the enquiry proceeds further and, Fourthly, it must be proved that the injury of the type just described made up of the three elements set out above is sufficient to cause death in the ordinary companyrse of nature.

concepts.interpretation: Four objective and subjective elements to establish murder under Section 300 thirdly: (1) bodily injury present, (2) nature of injury proved, (3) intention to inflict that injury, (4) injury sufficient to cause death in ordinary course.

arguments.claim: Virsa Singh did not actually have the intention to cause the death of Khem Singh but gave a rash and forceful blow which caused death, with peritonitis hastening it; case still falls under s. 300 thirdly

anchor.surface_text: When the common object of the assembly seems to have been to cause grievous hurts only, I do not suppose Virsa Singh actually had the intention to cause the death of Khem Singh, but by a rash and silly act he gave a rather forceful blow, which ultimately caused his death. Peritonitis also supervened and that hastened the death of Khem Singh. But for that Khem Singh may perhaps not have died or may have lived a little longer. Basing on those facts, he said that the case fell under s. 300, 3rdly

arguments.claim: Per Steane, if totality of evidence leaves room for more than one view on intent or doubt, prosecution fails and accused entitled to acquittal

anchor.surface_text: the learned Chief Justice says that if, on the totality of the evidence, there is room for more than one view as to the intent of the prisoner, the jury should be directed that it is for the prosecution to prove the intent to the jurys satisfaction, and if, on a review of the whole evidence, they either think that the intent did not exist or they are left in doubt as to the intent, the prisoner is entitled to be acquitted.

arguments.claim: Per Steane, prosecution proving act with natural consequences and no evidence/explanation allows finding of alleged intent

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, if the prosecution prove an act the natural consequences of which would be a certain result and no evidence or explanation is given, then a jury may, on a proper direction, find that the prisoner is guilty of doing the act with the intent alleged.

arguments.court_reasoning: Links intent with seriousness of injury contrary to section which separates them; intent is to the injury proved, not its degree/seriousness

arguments.claim: No licence to inflict injuries sufficient to cause death in ordinary course claiming lack of intent; must face consequences unless accidental/unintentional shown

anchor.surface_text: No one has a licence to run around inflicting injuries that are sufficient to cause death in the ordinary course of nature and claim that they are not guilty of murder. If they inflict injuries of that kind, they must face the consequences and they can only escape if it can be shown, or reasonably deduced that the injury was accidental or otherwise unintentional.

holdings.text: The facts disclose an offence of murder under Section 302 IPC as the prosecution proved intention to inflict the particular bodily injury which was sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued with much circumlocution that the facts set out above do number disclose an offence of murder because the prosecution has number proved that there was an intention to inflict a bodily injury that was sufficient to cause death in the ordinary companyrse of nature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts' findings on injury and causation accepted; applies four-part test to facts showing all elements met, rejecting lack of intent argument.

holdings.text: The argument that Section 300 thirdly requires intention not only to the bodily injury but also knowledge that it is sufficient to cause death is fallacious; the clauses are disjunctive with intention subjective to injury and sufficiency objective.

anchor.surface_text: Section 300, 3rdly was quoted If it is done with the intention of causing bodily injury to any person and the bodily injury intended to be inflicted is sufficient in the ordinary companyrse of nature to cause death. It was said that the intention that the section requires must be related, number only to the bodily injury inflicted, but also to the clause, and the bodily injury intended to be inflicted is sufficient in the ordinary companyrse of nature to cause death.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis shows clauses separate; requiring knowledge of sufficiency would render thirdly redundant as it would fall under first clause (intent to kill).

holdings.text: To establish murder under Section 300 thirdly, prosecution must prove four elements: (1) bodily injury present (objective), (2) nature of injury proved (objective), (3) intention to inflict that particular injury (subjective), (4) injury sufficient to cause death in ordinary course (objective).

anchor.surface_text: To put it shortly, the prosecution must prove the following facts before it can bring a case under s. 300, 3rdly First, it must establish, quite objectively, that a bodily injury is present Secondly, the nature of the injury must be proved These are purely objective investigations. Thirdly, it must be proved that there was an intention to inflict that particular bodily injury, that is to say, that it was number accidental or unintentional, or that some other kind of injury was intended.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Parses section into objective and subjective components; distinguishes intent to specific injury from its lethal potential; burden on prosecution throughout.

holdings.text: There was intention to inflict the particular bodily injury found (spear thrust penetrating abdomen, intestines protruding, food oozing) as no evidence or explanation rebuts natural inference from the forceful act.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, if the prosecution prove an act the natural companysequences of which would be a certain result and numberevidence or explanation is given, then a jury may, on a proper direction, find that the prisoner is guilty of doing the act with the intent alleged. That is exactly the position here. No evidence or explanation is given about why the appellant thrust a spear into the abdomen of the deceased with such force that it penetrated the bowels and three companyls of the intestines came out of the wound and that digested food oozed out from cuts in three places.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Steane principle: natural consequences of proved act (forceful spear thrust) infer intent absent rebuttal; perverse to conclude otherwise.

holdings.text: Linking intent under Section 300 thirdly with degree/seriousness of injury (as in Sardarkhan) is incorrect; intent is to the proved injury, separate from its objective sufficiency.

anchor.surface_text: Emperor Sardarkhan Jaridkhan  1  where Beaman J. says that- where death is caused by a single blow, it is always much more difficult to be absolutely certain what degree of bodily injury the offender intended. With due respect to the learned Judge he has linked  1   1917  I. L. R. 41 Bom. 27,29. 1503 up the intent required with the seriousness of the injury, and that, as we have shown, is number what the section requires.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes precedent; section separates subjective intent from objective seriousness; evidence may overlap but conceptually distinct.

holdings.text: No one has licence to inflict objectively lethal injuries claiming lack of murderous intent; must face murder consequences unless accident or lack of intent to that injury shown or inferred.

anchor.surface_text: No one has a licence to run around inflicting injuries that are sufficient to cause death in the ordinary companyrse of nature and claim that they are number guilty of murder. If they inflict injuries of that kind, they must face the companysequences and they can only escape if it can be shown, or reasonably deduced that the injury was accidental or otherwise unintentional.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Policy-based observation reinforcing strict proof requirements but not essential to decision.

anchor.surface_text: To put it shortly, the prosecution must prove the following facts before it can bring a case under s. 300, 3rdly First, it must establish, quite objectively, that a bodily injury is present Secondly, the nature of the injury must be proved These are purely objective investigations. Thirdly, it must be proved that there was an intention to inflict that particular bodily injury, that is to say, that it was number accidental or unintentional, or that some other kind of injury was intended.
